SDG_GOAL: 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
SDG_TARGET: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
SDG_INDICATOR: 3.1.2 Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel
STAT_CONC_DEF:
Births that are attended by skilled personnel helps to reduce the health risks to both the mother and child. According to WHO, the risk of complications and infection that can cause morbidity and mortality to mother or baby can be reduced with proper medical attention during delivery.

Proportion of births attended by skilled personnel (generally doctors, nurses or midwives but can refer to other health professional providing childbirth care) is the proportion of child births attended by professional health personnel. Skilled attendants are medical doctor, nurse and auxiliary nurse midwife (ANM) in Nepal.

According to current definition provided by WHO, these are competent maternal and new born health (MNH) professionals educated, trained and regulated national and international standards. They are competent to:

  1. Provide and promote evidence-based, human rights based, quality, socio-culturally sensitive and dignified care to women and new born
  2. Facilitate physiological process during labour and delivery to ensure a clean and positive childbirth experience
  3. Identify and manage or refer women and / or new-borns with complications
SOURCE_TYPE: An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.
COLL_METHOD:
The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 were oversampled. Where 13 households with children under 5 and 12 households without were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the Final Report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires
INST_MANDATE: National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.
RATIONALE: Having a skilled health care provider at the time of child birth is an important lifesaving intervention for both women and new-borns. Not having access to this key assistance is detrimental to women's and new-borns health because it could cause the death of the women and/or the new born or long lasting morbidity Achieving universal coverage for this indicator is therefore essential for reducing maternal and new born mortality.
REC_USE_LIM: Births attended by skilled health personnel is an indicator of health care utilization. It is a measure of the health system’s functioning and potential to provide adequate coverage for childbirth. On its own, however, this indicator does not provide insight into the availability or accessibility of services, for example in cases where emergency care if needed. Neither does this indicator capture the quality of care received
DATA_COMP:
This indicators is calculated by dividing the total number of women aged 15-49 years with a live births in the last 2 years whose most recent live births was attended by skilled personnel by the total number of live births in the same period multiplied by 100.

Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel = Number of women age 15-49 years with a live birth in the last 2 years whose most recent live birth was attended by skilled health personnel /Total number live births×100
DATA_VALIDATION:
Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
DOC_METHOD: It follows the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF.
QUALITY_MGMNT: Central Bureau of Statistics is the official agency to conducts survey and census. It has trained manpower

Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

COVERAGE: The data is available by province and rural and urban.
COMPARABILITY: It follows MICS 6 guidelines of UNICEF and can be compared across countries.
OTHER_DOC: Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), 2020. Nepal Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019, Survey Findings Report. Kathmandu, Nepal: Central Bureau of Statistics and UNICEF Nepal.
